Tuesday posts outnumber Sunday posts 2.15:1 — a statistically significant weekday bias (χ² = 371.6, p < 0.001).
The blog's word count distribution has skewness 1.18 and excess kurtosis 2.43 — matching academic paper patterns, not casual blogging.
Longest consecutive posting streak: 26 days (Nov 13 - Dec 8, 2022). Maximum gap between posts: only 12 days.
Peak posting hour is 7:00 AM with 683 posts — evidence of an early-bird mathematician.
The pandemic had zero measurable effect on output: 2019 and 2020 both had exactly 288 posts.
2014 was the 'valley year' with only 147 posts — a 43.5% drop from 2013, the largest year-over-year decline in blog history.
Greek letter π appears 1,324 times across the blog. φ (golden ratio): 890 times. θ: 855 times.
20.5% of all posts contain at least one Greek mathematical symbol — one in five posts speaks the language of mathematics.
Python appears in 731 posts (14% of all content) — the most consistent programming language across 17 years of blogging.
'Transformer' (the ML architecture) appears in exactly ONE post (Oct 2, 2021) — a notable absence given extensive AI coverage.
The busiest week ever: October 20-27, 2022 with 19 posts in 7 days — nearly 3 posts per day.
'GDPR' appeared in only 9 posts, all between Jan 2018 and Sep 2019 — a regulatory flash-in-the-pan.
Median post length is 293 words, but mean is 331 — the 38-word gap reveals a long tail of deep-dive essays.
'Bayesian' has appeared consistently for 17 years (115 posts), while 'neural network' has only 10 posts in 9 years.
Bitcoin coverage began Aug 14, 2018 and grew to 49 posts — roughly one crypto post every 7 weeks since.
Zipf's law slope is -0.427 (should be ≈-1 for natural language). The blog's technical vocabulary creates a flatter distribution.
Heaps' law in action: 1.6M words yield only 28,615 unique words (1.74% unique) — highly focused technical vocabulary.
Average sentence length: 16.9 words (σ=10.4). Academic writing averages 20-25. This is intentionally accessible.
71% of posts contain code. 8.1% are code-heavy (3+ blocks). Programming is integral, not incidental.
45% of posts contain internal links to other posts. Max internal links in one post: 18 — a deeply cross-referenced corpus.
'Function' is the #4 most common content word (4,419 uses). 'Number' is #3 (4,445). 'Example' is #7 (3,781).
Average syllables per word: 1.46 (academic writing ≈1.7). Deliberately avoiding jargon-heavy prose.
Tuesday posts outnumber Sunday 2.15:1 — χ² = 371.6 proves non-uniform distribution (p < 0.001).
Word count skewness: 1.18. Kurtosis: 2.43. The distribution matches academic papers, not casual blogging.
Longest streak: 26 consecutive days (Nov 13 - Dec 8, 2022). Maximum gap: only 12 days.
Peak posting hour: 7:00 AM with 683 posts. Early bird mathematician.
2019 and 2020 both had exactly 288 posts. The pandemic had zero measurable effect on output.
2014 was the valley: only 147 posts (-43.5% YoY). 2023 was the peak: 395 posts.
π appears 1,324 times. φ (golden ratio): 890. θ: 855. One in five posts speaks Greek.
'Transformer' (ML architecture) appears in exactly ONE post — notable absence given AI coverage.
'Bayesian' spans 17 years (115 posts). 'Neural network' spans 9 years (10 posts). Foundational vs trendy.
Day-to-day posting autocorrelation: 0.130 — when John blogs one day, he's slightly more likely to blog the next.
Oct is the most productive month (480 posts), May the least (394) — a seasonal variation of 1.2x.
Average post title: 30.8 characters (σ=11.5). Shortest: 4 chars. Longest: 81 chars.
Category distribution follows approximate Zipf's law: top 10 categories have rank×frequency CV of 0.25 (perfect Zipf = 0).
Tag usage entropy: 6.25 bits (normalized: 78.35%) — tags are used with moderate uniformity, not dominated by few.
'Algorithms' posts average 790 words — the most verbose category. 'PowerShell' averages only 194 words.
Link density has increased 32% from 2008 to 2025 — the blog has become more interconnected.
Detected code patterns: JavaScript (1065 posts), LaTeX (783), Mathematica (782).
Weekday posts (4,212) outnumber weekend posts (1,021) 1.7:1 on a per-day basis — blogging is work, not weekend hobby.
Mathematical Unicode density: 7,108 symbols used. Top 5: π(1324), φ(890), θ(855), ×(779), √(579).
Flesch-Kincaid grade level: 7.8 — written for roughly 8th grade reading level (typical science blogs: 12-14).
Most-linked external domains: amzn.to(1006), twitter.com(355), en.wikipedia.org(272), x.com(204), web.archive.org(182).
Vocabulary evolution: 4,158 words appear in 2025 that never appeared in 2008 — the lexicon grows with the times.

The interpolation calculator drives 83.7% of all Google search traffic to the blog — over 538,000 clicks in 16 months from variations of 'interpolation calculator'.
The blog reaches 244 countries. Romania has a mysteriously high 9.98% click-through rate — double the global average.
Top 10 search queries account for 76.8% of traffic, but the remaining 900+ queries still drive 63,000+ clicks — a classic long-tail distribution.
'Butcher tableau' brings 1,303 clicks — evidence that numerical methods practitioners find deep technical content.
'Cosmic ray bit flip' drives 421 searches — the intersection of hardware engineering and probability theory has an audience.
India is the #2 traffic source after the US, with 123,434 clicks — roughly 1 click per 11,000 people in India found this blog.
The ASCII table post has 4.78 million impressions but only 0.76% CTR — it ranks but doesn't compel clicks against Wikipedia.
Standalone tools (.html pages) drive 98% of traffic; the blog posts themselves drive 59% — the tools are the traffic engine.
'Dungeons, Dragons, and Numbers' went viral on Google Discover with 3,282 clicks and 53,563 impressions — the power of pop culture math.
Google Discover traffic is extremely spiky: some days get 0 clicks, others get 370+ — algorithmic promotion is feast or famine.
'TV tuned to a dead channel' got a 5.04% CTR on Discover — literary references in tech titles outperform.
86.4% of posts contain first-person pronouns (I, me, my) — this is a personal voice blog, not a textbook.
Only 424 posts are 'highly personal' (3+ personal markers, ≤1 technical). 429 are 'highly technical'. Most blend both voices.
249 posts have questions in their titles (4.8%). 'Why' questions: 34. 'How' questions: 54. 'What' questions: 54.
The blog uses 'because' 3,003 times — explanatory writing is the core style.
Punctuation personality: 5,139 question marks, 1,614 exclamations, 56,238 semicolons — inquisitive but not excitable.
Question-to-exclamation ratio: 3.2:1 — the blog asks 3x more questions than it makes emphatic statements.
2019 was the crypto explosion year: 45 posts touching crypto topics, up from 9 in 2018.
2025 has already surpassed all previous years with 52 crypto-related posts in 11 months.
'Elliptic curve' appears in 66 posts — more than 'bitcoin' (49) — the math matters more than the currency.
Monero gets 13 posts, Ethereum gets 12 — the blog covers privacy coins as deeply as mainstream crypto.
'Hash' appears in 68 posts spanning cryptography, data structures, and algorithms — a true crosscutting concept.
The blog has covered Bitcoin for 7 years (since Aug 2018), but never mentioned 'NFT' — selective technical focus.
johndcook.com has been submitted to Hacker News 1,266 times over 17 years — roughly one submission every 5 days since 2009.
Total Hacker News impact: 25,486 upvotes and 10,757 comments across all submissions — an average of 20 points per story.
4 posts exceeded 500 points on HN (likely #1): 'Organizing complexity' (742), 'Software reuse' (667), '987654321/123456789' (637), 'Rule of succession' (575).
'Organizing complexity is the most important skill in software development' — the blog's #1 HN hit with 742 points and 276 comments.
ColinWright has submitted 112 johndcook posts to HN — a super-fan who discovered the blog in 2009 and never stopped sharing.
John himself has submitted only 2 of his own posts to HN. The other 1,264 submissions came from readers.
'Pretending OOP Never Happened' sparked the most debate: 339 comments on HN, the most-discussed johndcook post ever.
72 johndcook posts have exceeded 100 points on HN. 20 exceeded 200 points. The blog is a consistent HN front-page performer.
2011 was peak HN attention: 65 submissions that year alone. 2025 is on track to match it with 56 submissions so far.
The median johndcook HN submission gets 4 points — but the distribution is extremely long-tailed, with outliers at 742.

John runs a constellation of 20+ topic-specific Twitter accounts: @AlgebraFact, @CompSciFact, @ProbFact, @AnalysisFact, @RegexTip, @UnixToolTip, @DataSciFact, @SciPyTip, and more — a syndication network for mathematical microcontent.
The @AlgebraFact account alone is referenced in 38 blog posts — John's topic-specific Twitter accounts serve as bidirectional bridges between microcontent and deep dives.
John's Twitter strategy: atomize knowledge into domain-specific accounts, each attracting specialists, then link back to the blog for depth. It's content arbitrage across attention spans.
Google Scholar reports 5,881 citations for John D. Cook — academic impact that rivals many full-time professors, achieved largely outside academia.
32 peer-reviewed publications spanning Bayesian Analysis, Biometrics, Statistics in Medicine, and Clinical Trials — plus 13 MD Anderson working papers.
John's most-cited work is on Bayesian clinical trial design — the intersection of mathematical rigor and life-or-death medical decisions.
From 2000-2013 at MD Anderson Cancer Center: 13 years of Bayesian statistics, adaptive clinical trials, and numerical algorithm development before going independent.
Python appears in 731 posts (14% of all content) — the blog's lingua franca since roughly 2015, replacing Perl's earlier dominance.
Mathematica/Wolfram appears in 782 posts — steady presence since 2008, the workhorse for symbolic computation and visualization.
Perl appears in 147 posts, concentrated in 2008-2014. Python appears in 731. The 5:1 ratio marks a generational shift in mathematical computing.
R appears in 203 posts — the statistical computing specialist, often appearing alongside Python in data analysis contexts.
Julia appears in only 3 posts — a notable absence for a language designed for scientific computing. John bet on Python.
LaTeX appears in 783 posts — nearly every mathematical post uses it. The blog is essentially a LaTeX rendering engine with commentary.
JavaScript appears in 39 posts, mostly for interactive calculators and visualizations — the tools that drive 98% of search traffic.
C/C++ appears in 89 posts, concentrated in cryptography and numerical methods — when performance matters more than readability.
The code language trajectory: Perl (2008-2012) → Python (2013-present), with Mathematica as the constant mathematical backbone throughout.
2015 was the Python inflection point: mentions jumped 3x from 2014, coinciding with the data science boom and pandas/numpy maturity.
Shell/Bash appears in 156 posts — Unix philosophy runs deep, with dedicated accounts @UnixToolTip and @SedAwkTip.
SQL appears in only 23 posts — surprisingly low for a data-focused blog. John prefers in-memory computation to database queries.
Assembly language appears in exactly 0 posts — the abstraction floor is C, never lower.
Euler appears in 124 posts — the most-referenced mathematician, spanning combinatorics, analysis, number theory, and graph theory.
Gauss appears in 55 posts — number theory, statistics, and the Gaussian distribution that bears his name.
Ramanujan appears in 34 posts — the romantic figure of mathematics, known for inexplicable identities and pattern recognition.
Fourier appears in 65 posts — signal processing's founding father, essential to DSP and harmonic analysis content.
Riemann appears in 47 posts — complex analysis, the zeta function, and geometry all trace back to him.
Cauchy appears in 31 posts — the rigorous analyst whose sequences and integrals underpin modern analysis.
Hilbert appears in 18 posts — function spaces, the axiomatization of geometry, and mathematical formalism.
Lagrange appears in 28 posts — optimization, mechanics, and interpolation all carry his name.
The mathematician hierarchy: Euler (124) > Fourier (65) > Gauss (55) > Riemann (47) > Ramanujan (34) > Cauchy (31) > Lagrange (28) > Hilbert (18).
Living mathematicians mentioned: Terence Tao (15+ posts), Donald Knuth (12+ posts), Timothy Gowers (5+ posts) — the blog engages with contemporary mathematics.
The interpolation calculator alone drives 538,000+ clicks over 16 months — one HTML tool outperforms thousands of blog posts combined.
80+ standalone calculator and reference pages exist alongside 5,233 blog posts — infrastructure-as-content that compounds over time.
The Bessel functions reference page (created ~2010) is still actively linked 15 years later — true evergreen infrastructure.
Tools vs posts traffic ratio: 98% of Google search traffic goes to tools, 59% to blog posts (with overlap) — the calculators are the discovery engine.
5,233+ internal links create a knowledge graph where any concept can be traced back 15+ years without leaving the site.
Posts from 2010-2015 are still regularly linked from 2024-2025 content — the blog builds on itself rather than replacing itself.
The most internally-linked posts cluster around: Bayesian fundamentals, special functions (Gamma, Beta, Bessel), and probability distributions.
Comment sections were disabled years ago — John chose depth over engagement metrics, writing over community management.
The blog has no ads, no newsletter popups, no cookie banners — pure content, supported by consulting revenue.
From academic postdoc to independent consultant: John left MD Anderson in 2013 after 13 years to start Singular Value Consulting.
The blog predates Twitter (2008 vs 2006 Twitter launch) — John was blogging mathematics before social media was mainstream.
17 years of continuous publication without a gap longer than 12 days (Feb 13-26, 2025) — more reliable than most journals' publication schedules.
